lecture.lecture_title: Blow molding, compressive forming Introduction to powder processing Sintering, slurry processing

slide.text: 3.044 MATERIALS PROCESSING 3 Consolidation (Sintering) Mechanics of powder compaction are complex but well modeled: Driving Force 2P=Papplied+ Pr i capillary pressure/bracehtipupleft/bracehtipdownright/bracehtipdownleft/bracehtipuprightinternally/bracehtipupleft/bracehtipdownright/bracehtipdownleft/bracehtipupright trapped gas pressure Sintering: Papp0, if sintering in a vacuum Pi=0 Pressing: Papp/negationslash=0 uniaxialfast, but very limited in shapes isostatic, HIP (hot isostatic pressing) very good for closing small pores expensive, limited in shape Uses of Powder Production (1) ceramics processing (2) powder metallurgy(3) thermoset polymers(4) pharmaceuticals

3.044 MATERIALS PROCESSING LECTURE 20 Non-Newtonian Rheology =m Newtonian Flow (m 1) is desirable for ow stability against necking and void- ing/cavitation S of a rw eh a v et a l k e da b o u tnet tension . However, many processing operations are innet compression: extrusion rolling/bracerightbigg continuous injection molding forging/bracerightbigg batch What about ow stability? more forgiving, less concerned about min compression m>0.5 tension m>0.2 compression faster processing is possible Date : May 7th, 2012. 1
MIT OpenCourseWare http://ocw.mit.edu 3.044 Materials Processing Spring 2013 For information about citing these materials or our Terms of Use, visit: http://ocw.mit.edu/terms .

2 LECTURE 20 But we cant completely ignore m, there are some instabilities: barrelling (but it doesnt really matter) recrystallization cracksopvoids/bracerightbigg en on directions of tension How to process high Tmmaterials? e.g. Refractory metals (W, Ta, Mo), Tm= 30004000C, ceramics Al 2O3 Casting: too hot hard to melt what material do you use as a mold? must withstand the heat and not react containerless process, powder Viscous shape forming: need a solid block of material to begin with Powder Processing and Consolidation: volume reducing and forging Spray atomization and other containerless processes mostly for metals (few ceramics) Wet chemical processing e.g. Bayer process to make alumina clean powders, distributed sizes

q heat ux J = W 2m s ms : J WFouriers Law: q = kVT, k thermal conductivity m K :J KVT temperature gradient m Compare: Fouriers Law Ficks 1st Law q = kVT J = DVc Why does heat behave this way? Energy minimization Entropy maximization Heat Conduction Equation:
First think in 1-D Heat balance in a small element: heat in heat out (+ heat generation) = heat accumulationh ut n h ut n h ut n h ut n A qin A qout H chemical reaction, resistance V T H Aqin Aqout = V T

3 3.044 MATERIALS PROCESSING H qin qout = x T H q|x q|x+x = x T T T H k x |x x |x+x = x T H k T T T = x ( x |x+x x |x) k T = ( )x x = k (T x ) x H 2T = k T x2 How does H relate to T? where cp is heat capacity H = Tcp and is density H T = cpt t 2T T k = cpx2 t k 2T T = cp x2 t 2T T = x2 t T 2T = t x2 is the Thermal Diusivity : J Wk m K = : Jkg K m3 J cpkg 2k m = cps

4 LECTURE 1 The values of k, cp and for any material can be looked up in tables and do not need to be experimentally determined. Therefore is a materials property. Compare: Heat Conduction Equation T t = hutn 2T x2 Ficks 2nd Law c t = Dhutn 2c x2
thermal diusivity diusivity
Topic for Future Discussion: In 3-D ... T cp = V kVT t T = V2T t ** assuming k is constant with respect to the derivative h m2 si h m2 si

3.044 MATERIALS PROCESSING LECTURE 1 What is Materials Processing? - A way to make materials useful: desired chemistry, shape, microstructure - A way to give materials the desired properties What Processes are included in copper production? grinding colloid / suspension rening / reducing casting electrolysis melting casting rolling (hot) drawing What thermodynamic variables do we have to work with? T P (or ) C (composition) heat heat transfer beat (move matter) solid mechanics uid mechanics mix chemical reaction phase transformation diusion Topics Covered in this Class Part I: Heat transfer
Part II: Fluid ow
Part III: Combine all 3
Heat Conduction: Heat ows down the temperature gradient Date : February 8th, 2012. 1

slide.text: 2 LECTURE 22 lowpotential particles agglomerate in suspension aggregates settle larger voids, irregular structure in sintered body settling lower velocity settling spend more time going over the repulsive hillless occulation, more uniform settling slip casting highter velocity settling spend less time going over the re- pulsive hill and enter the occulation minimum more occulation, less uniform settling Add Macromolecules U=HTS adsorbed macromolecules add entropic repulsion eects Vacuum/Vapor Deposition Processes semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, MEMS, etc. coatings for decoration (furniture, sports equipment, faucetry) or abrasion resis- tance (cutting/machining, tooling, blades)

4 LECTURE 22 5. MBE - molecular beam epitaxy 6. plasma enhanced deposition PVD Energy Diagram: no chemical reaction: the deposition rate is as fast as atoms are supplied geometry dominated, source limited stsupplied ux,Jmol m2s ds=JdtVm,w h e r eV mis molar volume, geometry factor e.g.Evaporation PeJ=P 2MwRT wherePeis equilibrium vapor pressure, Pis pressure 0 (vacuum), and Mwis molecular weight Next time: CVD

3.044 MATERIALS PROCESSING 3 Two main classes of processes PVD CVD physical vapor deposition chemical vapor deposition vacuum process (low pressure) vapor process (high pressure) solid or liquid source gas source no chemical reaction, just adsorption chemical reactions occur geometry dominated uid ow and diusion dominated PVD 1. sputtering 2. e-beam 3. evaporation 4. pulsed laser deposition

2 LECTURE 8 CVD: Chemical Vapor Deposition At steady state the thermocouple outputs a temperature reading TTC TC is heated by gas (convection) in/bracehtipdownleft /bracehtipupright/bracehtipupleft /bracehtipdownright h(TTf)A=out/bracehtipdownleft /bracehtipupright/bracehtipupleft (T4 surfT4 source)A /bracehtipdownright TTC=Tf(T4 hsurfT4 source) TTC/negationslash=Tf Tf1000C,T wall500C, W=0.1,h= 100m2K TTC830C,T200C Conclusions: 1. Objects that see cold surroundings are colder than you think 2. If an object sees a hot source it can be unexpectedly hot3. In vacuum indicates no convection radiation must be important Topics Covered So Far: Heat Beat Mix heat transfer solid mechanics diusion uid mechanics phase transition

4 LECTURE 7 In a cavity: qe=qe,b=T4 What kind of boundary condition can we write? Net ux at the object: qnet=qemittedqradincoming =qe,bqrad =/parenleftbig T4 surfqrad =/parenrightbig /parenleftbig T4 surfT4 source =/parenrightbig /parenleftbig T4 surfT4 source/parenrightbig Summary: Tqcond=kx qconv=h(TTf) qnet=/parenleftbig T4 surfT4 source T4: rapid onset, importan/parenrightbig t at high T and irrelevant at low T T4 objT4 furnace: if the object is much colder than the furnace then you can assume T4 obj0

3.044 MATERIALS PROCESSING 3 Is there a real blackbody?: Sort of... there are cavities Light is emitted but cannot be lost: At p emission qe=wallqe,b At Q reection qQ=wallwallqe,b=( 1wall)wallqe,b At R reection #2 qR=wall(wallwallqe,b) At S reection #3 qS=wallwallwallwallqe,b After n reections qn=n wallwallqe,b Total qe=( 1+2 wall+wall+...)wallqe,b 1= 1wallqe,bwall wall= q1e,bwall wall=qe,bwall =qe,b

2 LECTURE 7 Governing Equation: T=t2T hLBir=R, where h = 10-20, L =k,a n dk=3 52 =smallno gradient in the solid ALONG r Solution: TTf1=TmTfer2/parenleftbigg fz 2+t/parenrightbigg /parenleftbigg+zerf2 t/parenrightbigg Radiative Heat Transfer In equilibrium: energy absorbed = energy emitted qrad=qe ABlack Body is an idealized solid that 1. absorbs everything: b=1 2. emits light perfectly (Planck, Stefan-Boltzman): qe,b=T4 is the Stefan-Boltzman constant = 5.669 x 108W m2K4 Blackbody in equilibrium: qrad,b=qe,b Most solids and liquids are not black but gray: qe=qe,b = emissivity: a unitless fraction of blackbody emmitted ux Another important note: =, for gray bodies emissivity = absorptivity

3.044 MATERIALS PROCESSING 5 To compare convection and conduction use: The Bi number To compare conduction and radiation use: kT=(T4 x surfT4 source) M=L kT3 surf If M>10, then radiation is fast, conduction is rate limiting If M<0.1, then conduction is fast (no gradients)

slide.text: 2 LECTURE 2 Taking k out of the derivative assumes that k = f(x) and k= f(T ), because T = f(x). Is this assumption valid? For most materials for most small working T ranges (< factor of 2) is usually negligible. Simplify the conduction equation: What we have done so far: T cp = V k VT t T = V2 T t 3D to 1D T 2T = t x2 Assumption 1: Steady State unchanging temperature with time (T prole), Steady State Conduction: heat is owing, but at constant rates everywhere T = V2T = 0 t V2T = 0 Laplace Equation 1-D Sheet and Bar 2T = 0 x2

Mission for the next part of the course: Focus on uid ow, How does uid ow relate to solid mechanics? How do we connect all three categories? Fluid Flow Terminology free ow - against low resistance medium (air) VS. conned ow - against a solid boundary/bracerightBigg incompressible ow - e.g. water, most melted/liquid matter Does pressure compressible ow - e.g. gases, polymer melts (mildly)/bracerightBigg change density? laminar ow - very uniform motion, low velocity turbulent ow - chaotic motion, high velocity
VS. Fluid Flow is the diusion ofmomentum Date : April 2nd, 2012. 1
